awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I: Lightweight Concrete Interlocking Masonry Blocks
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to improve job-site safety of dry-stacking installation of masonry walls without binding mortar through the use of novel Aerated Interlocking Masonry Units (AIMU). The AIMU multi-component wall system combines the advantages of wood and those of concrete and is potentially applicable for mid-rise multi-family housing, a key component of affordable housing stock in the US and worldwide.  These AIMUs can be laid quickly, safely, and accurately, reducing time and labor for cost-effective construction in the US and globally.  The proposed construction platform will improve durability and offer lower lifetime costs than standard wood-based wall construction.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will further develop a construction technology using masonry blocks via dry-stacking without binding mortar.  Aerated Interlocking Masonry Units (AIMU) are made of cellular lightweight concrete (CLC) and an activated adhesion. The proposed work will conduct testing to confirm the AIMU's ability to fill incursions and block irregularities, evaluate interfacial shear resistance between the interlocking features, and evaluate the interfacial adhesion activated through pressure or moisture. These fundamental properties are critical to resolving the primary barriers for translation of dry-stack masonry construction technology. The project will also demonstrate rapid outdoor dry-stacking AIMU installation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
STTR Award #2014964 Phase I: Testing of Local Crushing and Activated Adhesion Properties of CLC Global Aerated Interlocking Masonry Units for Dry-Stacking Construction and without Binding Mortar

CLC Global (CLCG) and University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM)

Research determined that 50 pcf cellular lightweight concrete (CLC) is best produced with binder-to-filler ratios by weight of 1:0.4 with fine sand, and cement-to-pozzolan ratio 0.75:0.25. Foam bubble lamellae thickness and strength is critical to the bubble durability, stability, size uniform dispersion throughout CLC mixture in the wet plastic state without bubble coalescence. Bubble wall integrity was best preserved by preparing aggregates to surface saturated condition, and water to cement ratio of .45:1. 

 CLCG transferred activated adhesion research to the hypothesis of thin-membrane glue mortar wet-stacked to meet US masonry code with Aerated Interlocking Masonry Unit (AIMU) blocks, requiring a thin section (20 mil) and 4 hour pot life for projected construction procedure. Glue mortar performance achieved 10 inch spreading diameter from a cone of 4 inch after mixing and remixing to form a thin film of 0.02~0.03 in. under a pressure of 0.3 psi; 8 hours initial set time, and a final set time 12-18 hours; one-day strength of 400 psi in compression and 30+ psi in tension/bond; 28-day strength of 1800 psi in compression and 80 psi in tension/bond. Polymer-modified cement-based glue mortar developed by UWM team met performance expectations in lab conditions. 

 Dry or wet-stacked AIMU blocks require CLC to microcrush to accommodate block surface irregularities and sand particles. Hundreds of local crushing tests at UWM with two steel punching heads of 3 mm and 5 mm in diameter determined required force for 3-mm particles at below 40 lbs, 5-mm particles below 80 lbs on average. Results indicated that localized micro-crushing of AIMU blocks, without reducing the structural integrity of the individual blocks, is viable, thus demonstrating the critical material property of CLC and CLCG AIMU commercialization. A detailed study of the microstructure of the CLC materials indicated that the forces needed to achieve local crushing increase with an increase in cell wall thicknesses.  

 UWM team studied the shear mechanism of AIMU walls in a variety of configurations, including  12 wallet tests (specimens with three-course AIMUs in single shear) and 8 triplet tests (three AIMUs in double shear) and the specimens represented three types of AIMU walls: dry-stack, wet-stack, and with grouted cells. The tests indicated that shear transfer in dry-stacked walls is through diagonal compression between AIMU interlocking features, and shear strength can be determined by the compressive strength of the CLC material. Secondly, wet-stacking glue provided additional shear strength, though bond strength can be affected by construction and limited by CLC material shear strength. Finally, the grout columns in wet-stacked and grouted walls contributed to shear strength.  Grout columns may not fail simultaneously, leading to highly variable contributions. Future investigations should be conducted to measure contribution of steel reinforced grout cores, and of both-sides surface bonding cement (SBC) coating providing an adhered planar diaphragm for in-plane and out-of-plane shear resistance. 

 CLCG performed trial production demonstrations in parallel with UWM laboratory work to assess commercial manufacturing viability of the AIMU products at a local small precast plant. The work was performed by 5 part-time semi-skilled laborers using light-duty equipment and tools. 120 AIMU gang forms were fabricated by CLCG following 4 iterations. Production ran for 12 days, with minor adjustments to improve production yields, ergonomic accommodations and logistics.  Each production task was measured in seconds. The pilot trial, extrapolated to a production magnitude of 2,000 AIMU blocks per day, estimated that 9 laborers 8 hour days can achieve forming, stripping forms and blocks, re-assembling forms, batching and conveyance by pumping, casting placement and inventory storage at .035 labor hours per unit of production. AIMU manufacturing processes with small precast operational methods is determined to be commercially viable, including with US labor costs. 

A 6-foot tall AIMU column was erected to demonstrate the speed of erection AIMU products. AIMU column exterior surface measured 36 square feet and was erected by one laborer in 20 minutes. By contrast a similar column erected with CMU blocks with bed and head mortar would require 2.5 hours at internationally recognized production rate. Other erection demonstrations show that 1000 square feet of AIMU wall 4.5’ high wall with no openings can be installed by one laborer in one day. By contrast a same-dimension CMU assembly requires one mason with a half time mortar tender 7.24 days to complete. The contrasting production rates of AIMU vs. CMU shows an extreme efficiency and a production cycle comparable to US wood construction production rates.

 


Last Modified: 01/16/2024
Modified by: Jian Zhao
